newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Deaf and dumb Romanian may be world's oldest human.
newsitem.headline: Deaf and dumb Romanian may be world's oldest human.

text.p: A Romanian deaf and dumb woman aged 115 may be the oldest person alive after the death of Frenchwoman Jeanne Calment at 122 in southern France last week.
Anicuta Butariu's birth certificate shows she was born on June 17, 1882 in the remote mountain village of Madrigesti, near the Hungarian border, her doctor Victor Arsenie said on Friday.
That would make Butariu older than Danish-born American Christian Martensen, who is due to celebrate his 115th birthday on August 16 in a California retirement home.
He was initially believed to have become the oldest living person after the death of Calment, who reached the highest age ever certified in a human being.
"Both her birth certificate and identity card show that date of birth," Arsenie said by telephone from the retirement home he runs in Lipova, 500 km (300 miles) northwest of Bucharest.
"Going by that, she seems to be the oldest person in the world now."

Butariu worked as a housekeeper until 1964, the year when late communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu started his 25-year reign. At age 82, police brought her to the retirement home, owned by Franciscan monks until it was confiscated in 1949 by the communist government.
Butariu shares a room with 14 other elderly people and became confined to a wheelchair only recently.
"She is a small, small bent woman," Arsenie said. "Everyone is astonished to see her eyes full of life."
Investigations in Butariu's native village showed that she might have had a brother or a sister. But Arsenie said all her known relatives had died.
"As far as I know, not a single relative has visited her here all these years," he said.
He added that she had not been told of her new-found status.
"It's very difficult to communicate with her," he said. "We have a minimum of gestures we regularly use to get along."
Arsenie said Butariu was "perfectly balanced from the medical point of view, with no chronic suffering".
"It's a pity she cannot talk to tell us what her life was like in this stormy century. Her vivid eyes seem to want to say a lot."
He had no ready explanation for her longevity.
"She must have a certain genetic structure that allowed her to live to such an age," he said. "But in practice, it is a simple coincidence. Anyone could have lived to that age."
